defs.docs: MIO bindings for Unix Domain Sockets

attributes.value: / MIO bindings for Unix Domain Sockets
cfg(unix)
deny(missing_docs)

defs.name: UnixDatagram
defs.docs: A Unix datagram socket.

attributes.value: / A Unix datagram socket.

defs.name: bind
defs.docs: Creates a Unix datagram socket bound to the given path.

attributes.value: / Creates a Unix datagram socket bound to the given path.

defs.name: from_datagram
defs.docs:
Consumes a standard library `UnixDatagram` and returns a wrapped
 `UnixDatagram` compatible with mio.

attributes.value: / Consumes a standard library `UnixDatagram` and returns a wrapped
/ `UnixDatagram` compatible with mio.
/ The returned stream is moved into nonblocking mode and is otherwise
/ ready to get associated with an event loop.

defs.name: pair
defs.docs: Create an unnamed pair of connected sockets.

attributes.value: / Create an unnamed pair of connected sockets.
/ Returns two `UnixDatagrams`s which are connected to each other.

defs.name: unbound
defs.docs: Creates a Unix Datagram socket which is not bound to any address.

attributes.value: / Creates a Unix Datagram socket which is not bound to any address.

defs.name: connect
defs.value: pub fn connect<P: AsRef<Path>>(&Self, P) -> io::Result<()>
defs.docs: Connects the socket to the specified address.

attributes.value: / Connects the socket to the specified address.
/ The `send` method may be used to send data to the specified address.
/ `recv` and `recv_from` will only receive data from that address.

defs.name: try_clone
defs.docs: Creates a new independently owned handle to the underlying socket.

attributes.value: / Creates a new independently owned handle to the underlying socket.
/ The returned `UnixListener` is a reference to the same socket that this
/ object references. Both handles can be used to accept incoming
/ connections and options set on one listener will affect the other.

defs.name: local_addr
defs.docs: Returns the address of this socket.

attributes.value: / Returns the address of this socket.

defs.name: peer_addr
defs.docs: Returns the address of this socket's peer.

attributes.value: / Returns the address of this socket's peer.
/ The `connect` method will connect the socket to a peer.

defs.name: recv_from
defs.docs: Receives data from the socket.

attributes.value: / Receives data from the socket.
/ On success, returns the number of bytes read and the address from
/ whence the data came.

defs.name: recv
defs.docs: Receives data from the socket.

attributes.value: / Receives data from the socket.
/ On success, returns the number of bytes read.

defs.name: send_to
defs.value: pub fn send_to<P: AsRef<Path>>(&Self, &[u8], P) -> io::Result<usize>
defs.docs: Sends data on the socket to the specified address.

attributes.value: / Sends data on the socket to the specified address.
/ On success, returns the number of bytes written.

defs.name: send
defs.docs: Sends data on the socket to the socket's peer.

attributes.value: / Sends data on the socket to the socket's peer.
/ The peer address may be set by the `connect` method, and this method
/ will return an error if the socket has not already been connected.
/ On success, returns the number of bytes written.

defs.name: take_error
defs.docs: Returns the value of the `SO_ERROR` option.

attributes.value: / Returns the value of the `SO_ERROR` option.

defs.name: shutdown
defs.docs: Shut down the read, write, or both halves of this connection.

attributes.value: / Shut down the read, write, or both halves of this connection.
/ This function will cause all pending and future I/O calls on the
/ specified portions to immediately return with an appropriate value
/ (see the documentation of `Shutdown`).

defs.name: UnixListener
defs.docs: A structure representing a Unix domain socket server.

attributes.value: / A structure representing a Unix domain socket server.
/ This listener can be used to accept new streams connected to a remote
/ endpoint, through which the `read` and `write` methods can be used to
/ communicate.

defs.name: bind
defs.docs: Creates a new `UnixListener` bound to the specified socket.

attributes.value: / Creates a new `UnixListener` bound to the specified socket.

defs.name: from_listener
defs.docs:
Consumes a standard library `UnixListener` and returns a wrapped
 `UnixListener` compatible with mio.

attributes.value: / Consumes a standard library `UnixListener` and returns a wrapped
/ `UnixListener` compatible with mio.
/ The returned stream is moved into nonblocking mode and is otherwise
/ ready to get associated with an event loop.

defs.name: accept
defs.docs: Accepts a new incoming connection to this listener.

attributes.value: / Accepts a new incoming connection to this listener.
/ When established, the corresponding `UnixStream` and the remote peer's
/ address will be returned as `Ok(Some(...))`. If there is no connection
/ waiting to be accepted, then `Ok(None)` is returned.
/ If an error happens while accepting, `Err` is returned.

defs.name: accept_std
defs.docs: Accepts a new incoming connection to this listener.

attributes.value: / Accepts a new incoming connection to this listener.
/ This method is the same as `accept`, except that it returns a `net::UnixStream` *in blocking mode*
/ which isn't bound to a `mio` type. This can later be converted to a `mio` type, if
/ necessary.
/ If an error happens while accepting, `Err` is returned.

defs.name: try_clone
defs.docs: Creates a new independently owned handle to the underlying socket.

attributes.value: / Creates a new independently owned handle to the underlying socket.
/ The returned `UnixListener` is a reference to the same socket that this
/ object references. Both handles can be used to accept incoming
/ connections and options set on one listener will affect the other.

defs.name: local_addr
defs.docs: Returns the local socket address of this listener.

attributes.value: / Returns the local socket address of this listener.

defs.name: take_error
defs.docs: Returns the value of the `SO_ERROR` option.

attributes.value: / Returns the value of the `SO_ERROR` option.

defs.name: UnixStream
defs.docs: A Unix stream socket.

attributes.value: / A Unix stream socket.
/ This type represents a `SOCK_STREAM` connection of the `AF_UNIX` family,
/ otherwise known as Unix domain sockets or Unix sockets. This stream is
/ readable/writable and acts similarly to a TCP stream where reads/writes are
/ all in order with respect to the other connected end.
/ Streams can either be connected to paths locally or another ephemeral socket
/ created by the `pair` function.
/ A `UnixStream` implements the `Read`, `Write`, `Evented`, `AsRawFd`,
/ `IntoRawFd`, and `FromRawFd` traits for interoperating with other I/O code.
/ Note that all values of this type are typically in nonblocking mode, so the
/ `read` and `write` methods may return an error with the kind of
/ `WouldBlock`, indicating that it's not ready to read/write just yet.

defs.name: connect
defs.docs: Connects to the socket named by `path`.

attributes.value: / Connects to the socket named by `path`.
/ The socket returned may not be readable and/or writable yet, as the
/ connection may be in progress. The socket should be registered with an
/ event loop to wait on both of these properties being available.

defs.name: from_stream
defs.docs:
Consumes a standard library `UnixStream` and returns a wrapped
 `UnixStream` compatible with mio.

attributes.value: / Consumes a standard library `UnixStream` and returns a wrapped
/ `UnixStream` compatible with mio.
/ The returned stream is moved into nonblocking mode and is otherwise
/ ready to get associated with an event loop.

defs.name: pair
defs.docs: Creates an unnamed pair of connected sockets.

attributes.value: / Creates an unnamed pair of connected sockets.
/ Returns two `UnixStream`s which are connected to each other.

defs.name: try_clone
defs.docs: Creates a new independently owned handle to the underlying socket.

attributes.value: / Creates a new independently owned handle to the underlying socket.
/ The returned `UnixStream` is a reference to the same stream that this
/ object references. Both handles will read and write the same stream of
/ data, and options set on one stream will be propogated to the other
/ stream.

defs.name: local_addr
defs.docs: Returns the socket address of the local half of this connection.

attributes.value: / Returns the socket address of the local half of this connection.

defs.name: peer_addr
defs.docs: Returns the socket address of the remote half of this connection.

attributes.value: / Returns the socket address of the remote half of this connection.

defs.name: take_error
defs.docs: Returns the value of the `SO_ERROR` option.

attributes.value: / Returns the value of the `SO_ERROR` option.

defs.name: shutdown
defs.docs: Shuts down the read, write, or both halves of this connection.

attributes.value: / Shuts down the read, write, or both halves of this connection.
/ This function will cause all pending and future I/O calls on the
/ specified portions to immediately return with an appropriate value
/ (see the documentation of `Shutdown`).

defs.name: read_bufs
defs.docs: Read in a list of buffers all at once.

attributes.value: / Read in a list of buffers all at once.
/ This operation will attempt to read bytes from this socket and place
/ them into the list of buffers provided. Note that each buffer is an
/ `IoVec` which can be created from a byte slice.
/ The buffers provided will be filled in sequentially. A buffer will be
/ entirely filled up before the next is written to.
/ The number of bytes read is returned, if successful, or an error is
/ returned otherwise. If no bytes are available to be read yet then
/ a "would block" error is returned. This operation does not block.

defs.name: write_bufs
defs.docs: Write a list of buffers all at once.

attributes.value: / Write a list of buffers all at once.
/ This operation will attempt to write a list of byte buffers to this
/ socket. Note that each buffer is an `IoVec` which can be created from a
/ byte slice.
/ The buffers provided will be written sequentially. A buffer will be
/ entirely written before the next is written.
/ The number of bytes written is returned, if successful, or an error is
/ returned otherwise. If the socket is not currently writable then a
/ "would block" error is returned. This operation does not block.
